(Translated by Google) I was ordered to the surgery at 7 a.m. last June for a displaced wrist fracture, fasting, and shouldn't take my blood pressure medication or pain reliever. I was there without fluids and in severe pain until 5 p.m. I had no bell and could not go to the toilet with my open shirt. The sun popped into the room, it was scorching hot. In my distress I called my daughter, who then came and accompanied me to the toilet and then spoke to the sisters to ask why it was that I had been drinking for 10 hours and without getting anything for my pain in the storage room. Strangely, I was taken to the operating room 10 minutes later. The anesthetist there was amazed that my blood pressure was 240/140, which didn't surprise me. I was supposed to stay there for two days after the operation, but was released the next day in the morning. The operation itself went very well, but the whole thing was catastrophic. It took me several days to recover from this bad hospital stay.

Name: KRH Klinikum Lehrte
Kommentare:
(Translated by Google) This jack disappointed me severely and I express myself extremely politely. I could neither stand nor walk and was driven to this clinic with KRKW. I did not meet the formal requirements for admission, but despite new pain relievers I was unable to move on my own. I was supposed to be picked up a little later. And I was already alone again. Well, I thought I'd give it a try. But I had no reception. Either vaccinated by the doctor or just unfriendly, an older sister asked me why I was still here. When I wanted to tell her she turned away and I just said flippantly that she probably didn't care anyway. Then she asked. Afterwards I had another short dialogue with the doctor of the emergency department and told him that I had a nice home and would rather be there. But only if I'm healthy. We both stayed so that I should wait a short while until the painkillers he administered worked and then I should go or he would take me to the hospital. To my bad luck these painkillers did not help either and I had to be admitted. I also tried to understand the doctor's situation and decided that I would like to forget the incident and concentrate on my recovery. I did the same. An older sister took me again and she also had a bad mood. I didn't want to take that personally either, because I was already somewhat negatively influenced. And as you know, a night's sleep always helps. In the early morning, the older sister from ward 3 led a new patient into the room. Her wording: "everyone is still sleeping here ... no matter" and then the light went on. The patient, on the other hand, tried to be quiet and the older sister spoke to the patient at full volume. That was a behavior that was really not possible and then I slowly but surely got angry. So far, I had not experienced a bit of friendliness and even with all the stress, one should not forget that it is people and not numbers. During my stay I also came across unfriendly and stressed doctors and nurses. Now I am sitting in my bed on day 3 and have decided that, should I be conscious, I will always say that I don't want to be taken to the Lehrter hospital because of hell. As devastating as this judgment may sound, it is my firm decision. I could have gone into a lot more detail or told about other patients I met here who shared the same opinion, but I would prefer to avoid this because this is only about my personal opinion. Conclusion never again Lehrter Krankenhaus.

PS: To the few friendly sisters, keep it up and head high. You do a great job.

Ihr Wortlaut.: ‚Äúhier schlafen ja noch alle....egal‚Äú und dann ging das Licht an der Patient bem√ºhte sich hingegen leise zu sein und die √§ltere Schwester sprach in ihrer vollen Lautst√§rke mit dem Patienten. Auch im Verlaufe meines Aufenthaltes stie√ü ich immer wieder auf unfreundliche und gestresste √Ñrzte und Schwestern. Nun sitze ich am Tag 3 in meinem Bett und habe beschlossen das ich, sollte ich bei Bewusstsein sein, immer sagen werde das ich auf Teufel komm raus nicht ins Lehrter Krankenhaus gebracht werden m√∂chte.
